title: So, it seems like the communities first reaction to this preseason patch is...
body:
OH GOD MAKE IT STOP. I don't remember last preseason being like this. I'm sure there must have been some vitriol over the jungle changes. But, the game just feels completely out of whack all over the place this year.

Does anyone remember if the communities response to the preseason patch last year was this negative?

replies.body: Last preseason ruined the jungle so the rage was contained to junglers, sympathizers, (edit: Warwick victims,) and people sick of seeing Lee since it's the utmost importance to make sure he has no issues with changes.   This preseason ruined the entire game - it wasn't nearly this bad last year.
I don't think people omplained that much the last time they reworked masteries

That's because they were still trees and it was  just an annoyance to reset the masteries.  What we have now...you really think these are talent trees?  You're well on your way to becoming Blizzard, Riot.  It's something no one in this game with a WoW background wants to see.

Okay, since you seem to have quite a bit more thought than many others who I've noticed: What do people hate so much about the new masteries vs the old ones? Is it the fact that each level is this XOR that instead of this OR that? I personally like them since it means each mastery on its own can be more impactful rather than masteries being a tiny bit of several stats since you don't have the chance to stack different masteries with the same stats.

But really, why do people hate the new masteries so much? They didn't lose anything important (well, maybe spellblade, but that's not much compared to DFT.) except you can't go TANKTANKTANK or DAMAGEDAMAGEDAMAGE.

The over simplification of them is a major turn-off.  This was advertised as a way to make every champion feel unique, but because everything is cookie cutter "take this or this, that's it" and lack of ability to devote more than 18 points into the so-called tree is creating an environment where everything is the same, in a much worse way than the last mastery set.

It also forces you to invest points into things you don't want just to get the one talent you feel is necessary.  If I'm going for a scaling damage build, why would I want scaling AP to go with my AD?  If I want to play an AP champion, I literally have one option for a keystone...gee thanks. The keystones themselves are terrible just because everyone has the same thing.  If you're building crit, you go warlords - every ADC champ, if you go utility support, you go Windseaker...I'm really feeling the unique diversity here. And what happens when you want to try and invest points elsewhere to make some kind of mixed tree?  You're stuck trying to get past the "you need to put 5 points in this level or leave it alone" part of the tree, and then you've just gimped yourself because you don't have a keystone.

What I miss about the old ones, as I've stated above is the ability to have a lot of control over what you're selecting in a system that makes sense.  I'm an AP mage, and If I want damage, there's the offensive tree - no brainer, but I also want some defense with my leftover points - oh; I can use the _defensive_ tree...hmm but on second thought, I don't really need that, I can keep myself safe enough, so I can either go for more damage, or get some mana regen or speed from the utility tree.  But you know what?  I don't feel safe at all, so I'm going to go for a control mage instead and sacrifice some of my offesnive tree points and therefore damage to help my team and I survive by putting more points into utility and defense.  It's not meta, but it will help me survive, I'm not looking to carry - just trying to help and trying not to die.

See how much control I have?  And at no point does the fact that I may not hit the bottom point in the tree cripple me so hard it's as if I'm automatically underleveled. That last point you made about people not being able to go TANKTANKTANK or DAMAGEDAMAGEDAMAGE is why I think a lot of people are upset with this.  You don't have the freedom to do what you want with the masteries, ruining the feeling that what you can do with them can actually make each champion feel unique and play the way you want them to be played.  If Riot's goal was to create that, they fixed what wasn't broken...._again_.

If by "quite a bit if options" you mean:
"A or B?" with no variance within one tree. 
And when we get to the keystones you have an innovative 3rd option:
"A, B, or C!?"
Then yes plenty of choices to be made there!

The problem with the new masteries is they're very restrictive and don't provide much nuance or variety in your choices. 

While I won't purport that the old system was perfect, what it did have was choice. And yes as it stands the old masteries may have only been smaller changes they at least felt varied, and you actually had options. Not this illusion of choice that the new ones have. 

If you ask me, a combination of elements from the old tree, and the new "tree" would likely result in a pretty solid mastery system. 
-Keep the more impactful masteries
-But make them more varied
-Allow more choice and variety
-Allow for far more specialization
-Actually make the system a damn tree again
-Make the system more coherent by changing the trees back to "Offense", "Defense" and "Utility". Not the pretentious nonsense they're named now.

THAT would be a good mastery system.

I feel like fighters are the only ones that got a good deal out of the change. I see a lot of difference in keystone choices as far as, say, Riven, Talon, Xin, etc players go, and they all seem to work pretty well.

But on the other hand, Mages, ADC, Supports, Junglers and Tanks are pretty limited i.e. it's always the same thing, really.

Also, to me, his point was not necessarily about the keystones, but the points you have to spend to reach the keystones. The keystone masteries are so strong that you cannot pass up on them. That wasn't the case last season. The last mastery of each tree was certainly good, but it wasn't to the point of completely removing the option of not taking them. I remember using a 0/14/16 page for a while for some tank supports that didn't needed the last 5 points in utility. I also played around with 0/30/0 Leona for a while, which while not necessarily the best, did get me some laughs.

The current masteries force you to go 18 in one thing and then either 12 in another or 6/6. You can't put more than 18 points in a tree and specialize in that three, nor can you spread your points around a bit more freely as keystones are too strong.

And the worst to me, is having to choose X or Y, rather than X and Y. This is one of the most limiting changes (althouth the severe reduction in amount of masteries per tree is also up there).

My main problem is they have some balancing to do to make the keystone masteries benefit more champs right now and not be as overpowering on certain ones. (Yas, Trynd, Brand).

I also hate when getting Thunderbird's Decree, cause I feel like the first two tiers in the cunning tree are lackluster to the available tiers in the other two trees when you look at what someone getting Thunderbird's Decree wants for stats.

> You're well on your way to becoming Blizzard, Riot.  It's something no one in this game with a WoW background wants to see.

Well, you're wrong about that.  As a past and current WoW player (as well as League and other games ofc), I think the new talent system was a positive change for WoW and I think the new mastery system is potentially a positive change for LoL (once some power outliers are cleaned up, Warlord's Bloodlust for example).  Too many old talents were powerful without being interesting, so they didn't offer meaningful choice, just "take this or be bad".  Now they at least lead up to something playstyle-impacting with real tradeoffs.

The talent change (a lot less points, a lot more importance per point, more specific strengths and less "you do everything X% better") was certainly a *divisive* change for WoW, but don't make the mistake of thinking every one of a million other players agrees with *you*.

Any sufficiently large playerbase disagrees with itself about practically everything, and no matter what the devs do or don't do, someone complains.  That definitely *is* something Riot has in common with Blizzard, but it doesn't say much about what direction they should take with game balance -- only that the existence of complaints gives them 0 information because it was preordained.

I have a theory on what is king in the current state of the game (seeing similarities in what is good in Smite's Conquest map):

Waveclear (either through attack speed or aoe skills)
Tower Pushing (attack speed and damage)
Lockdown (and a lot of it)
Some ability to snowball and STAY ahead (like how some characters keep escalating without any hint of falling off)

In my previous games, it seems that when a champion has a form of reliable lockdown (Jax E, Alistar, Braum, Lux) you create teamfights that focus on the squishiest person (the adc) where that person can't escape, and thus deletes the team's entire damage output.
Brand and Jax are also pretty king (besides Yasuo and Tryndamere) because Jax can easily push towers thanks to his passive, and Brand has always been a strong aoe damage mage, with a strong wave pushing ability with his W. This as well as champs having the ability to have damage in their kit, as well as building tanky with a tank support is how the teamfights can get by easier, because if you have some strong tanky fighters, they can survive long enough to get a few rotations in their abilities to help kill the important targets and keep the important teammates alive.

However, what happened to the days when a Heimerdinger couldn't half-health a tower within 30 seconds?
League used to be so diverse with the tank changes and juggernaut (shudder) changes, that there was a unique choice in champ selection that didn't make it a win for either team based on who you picked, but more so how you played that match, and how the rest of your team played.
Plus, League isn't Smite.
We shouldn't have to make these Smite similarities during champ select to help us actually win lane.

I apologize for speaking out of turn, or if anything I am saying is untrue about what the game has turned into at the moment.
I'm also not having fun when my games are either really close wins that are really good games, or just pure stomps that have uncontrollable snowball champs in almost every lane.
Makes it hard to play with my friends when we are all trying to play as our favorite champs in the preseason, but it just doesn't work because the other team just seems to play as better champs in almost every lane and position.

I've been around to witness season 4 and 5 preseasons as well as this one. This current one is by far the most negatively received of all three. Junglers complained in the previous two since the jungle gets a new update every freaking year, but most concerns were dealt with in a timely manner. The support role in Pre4 was drastically changed as well, with the usual mixed reaction. But overall both years the players were genuinely excited and eager to see the new changes rolling out.

This year, it's a much different tone. I've never seen this amount of people saying things like "I'm leaving LoL" or "I'm going to play another game for a few months" and get upvoted for posting such things before. It's too many changes at one time, resulting in a greatly unbalanced mess that's barely playable in a serious manner. In the previous preseasons, any horridly unbalanced changes were brought into line quickly. This year, Riot seems content to let certain champions with certain items have all the fun.

And here's the thing. And this is one of the only times I'll ever dare do this, but as someone who's played for 3 years I think I speak for multiple people when I say: we can deal with the preseason being out of whack, and "big" changes, we as a playerbase can handle it maturely and learn to adjust. 

But this is a complete mess and Riot is unapologetic about it, the reason so many long time players are leaving/threatening to leave is not because "Riot ruined the game" it's because we see a negative trend in their thinking in that they would even green light something like this, let alone ignore fears and negative feedback and actually go through with it. 

Trial and error is not how you balance a game that's already established itself, and giving the players an ultimatum on how they're "supposed" to play is not how you keep customers. If they're willing to make changes like this, how much further will it go? 

When are we gonna get the patch notes that say "We're removing Evelynn and Yorick from the game because they just don't fit, and we can't balance them?" When are we gonna get the patch notes that say "We've implemented the ability to play the game from 1st person view because we've identified a market for that and (insert buzzwords here)?" When are we gonna get the patch notes that say "Instead of making a brand new game based on LoL's IP which we think you all might really enjoy, and have the resources to do, we're just going to turn LoL into that game?" It's in the patch notes we're reading now, but not all of us see it, those who do, are worried, saddened, and enraged. 

The company has become too unpredictable, too brazen, too willing to make what seem like unsolicited changes simply because they can. This type of headstrong thinking is necessary when you're doing something new, but devastating to something that's already established. Long time players want the thing they love polished, cherished and meticulously taken care of, they do not want it replaced with a new thing with the same name. This is not what long time players want, nor is it what they deserve to be quite honest. Before this preseason Riot was arguably the best game developer **_in the world_** at understanding these points, and it seems they've suddenly gone to the dark side. It's too much to bear for people who were here for a long time and see the differences.

For sure, it's always exciting and welcomed to have a few new additions here and there; Scuttle Crab, Dragon powers, some neat items with actives, etc., but too much at the same time leaves the game in an unbalanced state and the kind of unbalance state that is hard to work in since Riot might not tackle the right thing in the right order. I really hope they manage to prioritize their upcoming changes, nerfs and buffs in a way that is gonna help the game quickly. 

For instance, Pre Season 6 could have added its different aspects (Masteries, AD itemizations, AD Carry mini-reworks, etc.) in 2 patches or 3 maybe instead of a big one. This would have let some time between each updates to adjust everything along the way.

In my opinion, the new changes aren't this much broken when you look at them individually (with the exception of certain REALLY OP things). When thrown all at the same time in one patch, it's easy to blame a specific change for the mess while the reality might be even more complex since every single change in League of Legends, even the slightest change, has the power to buff or nerf something else indirectly.
